<TD VALIGN="bottom" ALIGN="right"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">25,804</FONT></TD></TR>
<TR>
<TD VALIGN="top"> <P STYLE="margin-left:1.00em; text-indent:-1.00em"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">75</FONT><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1" COLOR="#000000"><SUP>th</SUP></FONT><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2" COLOR="#000000">
percentile</FONT></P></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" ALIGN="right"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">15,046</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" ALIGN="right"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">28,317</FONT></TD></TR>
<TR BGCOLOR="#cceeff">
<TD VALIGN="top"> <P STYLE="margin-left:1.00em; text-indent:-1.00em"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Hershey</B></FONT></P></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" ALIGN="right"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">4,820</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" ALIGN="right"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">13,289</FONT></TD></TR>
</TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px;padding-bottom:3px;line-height:95%; vertical-align:top"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Because Hershey&#146;s revenues are lower than the median
revenues of the primary peer group, regression analysis is used to adjust the primary peer group compensation data for this difference. The Company establishes a target for each executive officer position&#146;s total direct compensation (base
salary, annual incentive and long-term incentive) level to fall within the 50</FONT><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1" COLOR="#000000"><SUP>th</SUP></FONT><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2" COLOR="#000000"> and 75</FONT><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1" COLOR="#000000"><SUP>th</SUP></FONT><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2" COLOR="#000000"> percentile of the size-adjusted primary peer group. While the Company targets total executive compensation between the
50</FONT><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1" COLOR="#000000"><SUP>th</SUP></FONT><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2" COLOR="#000000"> and 75</FONT><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1" COLOR="#000000"><SUP>th</SUP></FONT><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2" COLOR="#000000"> percentile of the size-adjusted primary peer group, the Committee&#146;s final determinations reflect consideration of the Company&#146;s and executive officer&#146;s performance, internal comparisons
and other factors. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Towers Perrin also provides compensation data for a subset of 15 primarily food, beverage and consumer products companies, which we
call the &#147;high-performing financial peer group.&#148; We use this group primarily for assessing our Company&#146;s financial performance against the industry. These companies also represent a more focused set of competitors for executive
talent. Since revenues and market capitalization for the high-performing financial peer group are generally larger than Hershey, the data for this group is used as a secondary reference point for purposes of assessing Hershey&#146;s compensation
levels. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>What other information does the Committee consider when making executive compensation decisions? </B></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">In addition to survey and other data relating to the competitive landscape, the Committee receives tally sheets providing detailed information regarding executive
compensation. Much of this information is reflected in the tables on pages 45 through 62 of this proxy statement. The Committee considers this information when it makes compensation decisions. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">An important factor in the Committee&#146;s deliberations is the anticipated cost of the various components of executive compensation. In 2005, we adopted the provisions
of Statement of Financial Accounting Standards No.&nbsp;123 (Revised 2004), <I>Share-Based Payments</I>, or SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;123R, relating to accounting for stock options and other stock-based awards. The accounting treatment for an award is
taken into consideration in the design and implementation of the annual or long-term incentive programs. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Section&nbsp;162(m) of the Internal Revenue Code
limits our ability to deduct certain compensation in excess of $1 million paid to our CEO or to other named executive officers. This limitation does not </FONT>
</P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">35 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">
<FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">apply to compensation that qualifies under applicable regulations as &#147;performance-based.&#148; The Committee has considered the effect of section 162(m)
on the Company&#146;s executive compensation program. It is the Committee&#146;s opinion that in administering the &#147;performance-based&#148; portion of the Company&#146;s executive compensation program (the Annual Incentive Program, or AIP,
stock options and performance stock units described below), it will attempt to satisfy the requirements for deductibility under section 162(m). However, the Committee believes it should retain the flexibility to exercise its judgment in assessing an
executive&#146;s performance and that the total compensation program for executive officers should be managed in accordance with the objectives outlined in the Company&#146;s compensation philosophy and in the best overall interests of the
Company&#146;s stockholders. Accordingly, some compensation may exceed the limitations or not meet the requirements for deductibility under section 162(m). </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman"
SIZE="2"><B>What are the individual components of the executive compensation program and why does the Company choose to pay them? How are the amounts for each component of executive compensation determined? </B></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Our executive compensation program includes three key components: base salary and benefits, an annual cash incentive program and a long-term incentive program consisting
of stock-based awards. The total compensation package provided by the Company (including pension benefits, supplemental retirement benefits, and other benefits) is considered by the Committee when determining each component of an executive
officer&#146;s compensation. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Base salary and related benefits serve as the foundation of the overall pay package and are geared toward attracting and
retaining the executive officer. Annual and long-term incentives &#150; variable or &#147;at-risk&#148; pay &#150; play an important role in motivating executive performance and in aligning executive pay practices with the interests of stockholders.
The variable or at-risk elements are designed to reward the achievement of both short- and long-term goals. The long-term incentives link a significant portion of each executive officer&#146;s total compensation directly to individual performance,
long-term Company performance versus internal objectives and relative to the high-performing financial peer group, and to Common Stock price. At the executive officer level, at-risk pay often will represent approximately 75% of total compensation.
</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Base Salary </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px;padding-bottom:3px;line-height:95%; vertical-align:top"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Salary reviews are conducted at the beginning of each year to compare each executive&#146;s salary to the 50</FONT><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1" COLOR="#000000"><SUP>th</SUP></FONT><FONT FACE="Times New Roman"
SIZE="2" COLOR="#000000"> and 75</FONT><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1" COLOR="#000000"><SUP>th</SUP></FONT><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2" COLOR="#000000"> percentile of the size-adjusted salary level of the companies in our primary peer
group. Salary adjustments are made based upon peer group comparisons, as well as Company and individual executive performance. Both financial and, where appropriate, non-financial performance measures are considered in making salary adjustments. If
an executive officer has responsibility for a particular business unit, this unit&#146;s financial results also are strongly considered. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">We set the
initial base salary for a new executive officer based upon an evaluation of his or her responsibilities and experience, as well as upon the salaries paid by us and other companies for comparable executive talent and the salary necessary to recruit
the individual to Hershey. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">In 2006, base salaries for Mr.&nbsp;Lenny and all of the Company&#146;s executive officers were compared with executives having
similar organizational responsibilities at companies in Hershey&#146;s primary peer group. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px;padding-bottom:3px;line-height:95%; vertical-align:top"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Each
Hershey executive&#146;s base salary was targeted to be at the 50</FONT><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1" COLOR="#000000"><SUP>th</SUP></FONT><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2" COLOR="#000000"> percentile level of his or her counterparts in
the size-adjusted primary peer group. Based upon its review, the Committee </FONT>
</P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">36 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">


 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">
<FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">approved base salary increases ranging from 2.7% to 7.8%, effective January&nbsp;1, 2006, for each of the named executive officers to decrease the gap
between their salaries and those of the size-adjusted primary peer group. See Column (c)&nbsp;of the Summary Compensation Table on page 45 for information regarding the base salary earned by Mr.&nbsp;Lenny and each of our other named executive
officers during 2006. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Annual Incentive Program </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Our
executive officers, as well as other key managerial and professional employees, are eligible to receive an annual cash incentive award under the Annual Incentive Program, or AIP, of the stockholder-approved Key Employee Incentive Plan, or Incentive
Plan. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Our philosophy in setting AIP objectives is to link the executive&#146;s payout opportunity directly to measures he or she most directly can affect.
Mr.&nbsp;Lenny and all executive officers reporting directly to him (including the named executive officers) have common financial objectives tied to total Company performance consistent with their management of the entire Company and not specific
business units. The Committee emphasizes a limited number of goals to better focus actions on identified, strategic business objectives. Performance targets are established in the context of our announced expectations for financial performance,
prior year results and market conditions. Year-over-year performance is emphasized with no incentive compensation granted for results below prior-year results, little or no incentive compensation payable for missing targets, and a high degree of
leverage to reward above-target performance. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">In 2006, participating executive officers other than Mr.&nbsp;Lenny were eligible to earn individual awards
expressed as a percentage of base salary. These percentages ranged between 50% and 70%. The final award was determined by multiplying the executive officer&#146;s base salary, the applicable target percentage, and a performance score calculated as
the sum of the corporate performance score and an individual performance score. Individual and short-term (annual) corporate performance objectives are established at the beginning of each year by the Committee. Separate business unit performance
objectives are also established at the beginning of each year by the Committee for key business unit managerial and professional employees participating in AIP. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman"
SIZE="2">For 2006, the corporate financial objectives for participating executive officers other than Mr.&nbsp;Lenny were weighted at 75% of the total performance score and the individual performance objectives were weighted at 25%. Had performance
scores exceeded the objectives for financial measures and/or individual performance expectations, an individual executive officer might have received more than his or her target percentage. For executive officers other than Mr.&nbsp;Lenny, the
maximum potential corporate performance score for 2006 was 200% and the maximum potential individual performance score was 150%. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The corporate performance
objectives for 2006 AIP award payments to executive officers other than Mr.&nbsp;Lenny were based on the following financial measures: growth in diluted earnings per share from operations, or EPS (weighted 40%), growth in consolidated net sales
(weighted 40%) and improved margins, as measured by earnings from operations before interest and taxes, or EBIT (weighted 20%). The actual targets were based on the Company&#146;s 2006 business plan and goals, which called for earnings and sales
growth rates and margin improvement in excess of the Company&#146;s long-term financial expectations of net sales growth of 3% to 4%, 9% to 11% growth in EPS and a 90 basis point improvement in EBIT margin. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">For Mr.&nbsp;Lenny, the Committee recommended to the independent directors that his final 2006 award be calculated on the basis of a contingent maximum grant of $3
million. An award at the </FONT>
</P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">37 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">
<FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">maximum was contingent upon his achievement of his 2006 corporate performance goal from among the corporate performance objectives for the other named
executive officers. The maximum amount for Mr.&nbsp;Lenny reflects the maximum award under the provisions of our Incentive Plan to ensure that the amount of AIP that might have been paid to him under the AIP would qualify as tax-deductible
performance-based compensation under section 162(m) of the Internal Revenue Code. The independent members of the Board approved the recommendation of the Committee regarding Mr.&nbsp;Lenny&#146;s 2006 contingent AIP award. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Since our actual corporate results for 2006 for all three measures fell below the target level, Mr.&nbsp;Lenny recommended and the Committee concurred that neither he
nor any of the executive officers reporting directly to him, including the named executive officers, should receive a payment under the AIP for 2006. The independent directors approved the Committee&#146;s recommendation and did not award a 2006 AIP
award to Mr.&nbsp;Lenny. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Long-Term Incentive Program </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman"
SIZE="2">To date, we have used awards of performance stock units, stock options and restricted stock units to provide long-term incentive compensation. These awards are made under the long-term incentive program of the Incentive Plan. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Performance Stock Units.</I>&nbsp;&nbsp;Performance stock units, or PSUs, are granted to those executive officers and other senior officers in a position to affect
the Company&#146;s long-term results. PSUs have been granted annually and are earned based upon the Company&#146;s performance over a three-year cycle. Each year begins a new three-year cycle. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">At the start of each three-year cycle, a target number of PSUs is established for each executive. This target is expressed as a percentage of the executive&#146;s annual
salary and determined as part of a total compensation package based on primary peer group benchmarks. The PSU award generally represents one-half of the long-term incentive portion of the total compensation package. For the 2006-2008 PSU cycle, the
target number of PSUs established for each executive was adjusted based upon his or her 2005 performance rating. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">At the end of each three-year cycle, the
Committee reviews whether the Company has achieved the established performance objectives to determine the percentage of the target number of PSUs earned. In determining whether performance objectives have been achieved, specific adjustments may be
made by the Committee to the Company&#146;s performance to take into account extraordinary or unusual items occurring during the cycle. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">For the three-year
performance cycle of 2004-2006, the award was based upon (i)&nbsp;the Company&#146;s three-year compound annual growth in EPS, measured against the median three-year compound annual growth in EPS of the high-performing financial peer group and
(ii)&nbsp;the cumulative three-year improvement in the Company&#146;s economic return on invested capital, or E-ROIC, measured against an internal target. Based upon the Company&#146;s financial performance during the 2004-2006 cycle of a 10.85%
compound annual growth rate in EPS and three-year E-ROIC of 19.12%, the Committee determined that 176.0% of the PSUs granted in 2004 were earned. See Columns&nbsp;(d) and (e)&nbsp;of the Option Exercises and Stock Vested table on page 51 for more
information regarding PSU awards for the 2004-2006 cycle. At the start of the performance cycle, the Committee determined that PSUs earned for the 2004-2006 cycle would be payable in cash or Common Stock or a combination of both cash and Common
Stock at the election of the executive. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">In 2004, the Committee recommended and the independent directors approved a special contingent grant of up to
80,000 PSUs payable to Mr.&nbsp;Lenny at the conclusion of the three-year </FONT>
</P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">38 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">


 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">
<FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">cycle beginning January&nbsp;1, 2004, and ended December&nbsp;31, 2006. The maximum grant of 80,000 PSUs was contingent upon achieving a compound annual
growth rate in net sales, excluding sales generated by acquisitions, of at least 4.5% over that period. The compound annual growth rate of our net sales, excluding sales generated by acquisitions, exceeded the maximum achievement level set in 2004
for this award. As a result, the Committee approved payment of the full contingent grant of 80,000 PSUs to Mr.&nbsp;Lenny as reflected in the Option Exercises and Stock Vested table. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The established performance measures for PSUs for the three-year cycle beginning in 2006 are the Company&#146;s three-year compound annual growth in EPS versus the median three-year compound annual growth in EPS of
the high-performing financial peer group, and the Company&#146;s cumulative three-year improvement in E-ROIC against an internal benchmark. The performance scores can range from 0% to 250%, with each factor weighted at 50%. These performance
measures are chosen and the metrics set to significantly reward achievement of top-quartile performance against the high-performing financial peer group and internal targets, and significantly less than target for below-average performance. The
three-year cycle reinforces our objective to build and sustain stockholder value over the long term and serves to retain executive talent. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">PSUs earned
during the 2006-2008 three-year cycle are payable in shares of Common Stock. The actual value received by each executive will be dependent upon the market value of the shares at the end of the cycle and our performance during the three-year cycle.
At the time of grant, the value of each PSU granted in 2006 was $56.30 and was based upon the average of the market closing prices of our Common Stock each trading day during December 2005. See Columns (f), (g)&nbsp;and (h)&nbsp;of the Grants of
Plan-Based Awards table on page 47 for more information about the PSUs granted in 2006. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Stock Options</I>.&nbsp;&nbsp;Another important element of our
long-term incentive compensation program is the award of stock options. Stock options are designed to align the interests of executives with those of stockholders. Stock options generally are granted annually to the Company&#146;s senior executive
group as well as to other key managerial and professional employees. Stock options entitle the holder to purchase a fixed number of shares of Common Stock at a set price during a specified period of time. Because stock options only have value if the
value of our Common Stock increases, they encourage efforts to enhance long-term stockholder value. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The Committee sets guidelines for the number of stock
options to be granted based on the total compensation package established in relation to the competitive compensation data. In 2006, the number of stock options granted to our executive officers was determined by multiplying base pay by the
&#147;market-competitive option target level,&#148; divided by the Black-Scholes value. The &#147;market-competitive option target level&#148; for each position is targeted to be one-half of the recipient&#146;s long-term incentive compensation
target award. The value of an option is determined using the Black-Scholes option-pricing model, as described in note 15 of the consolidated financial statements contained in the 2006 Annual Report to Stockholders that accompanies this proxy
statement. Executives performing below expectations did not receive a stock option award in 2006. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Stock options are awarded annually under the Incentive
Plan to all eligible recipients; however, the Committee may elect not to grant stock options in a given year. In order to have flexibility to provide stock option grants as recruitment, retention, performance recognition or promotion awards, the
Committee is authorized under the Incentive Plan to establish a stock option pool for use by our CEO for such purposes. The Committee establishes the stock option pool annually. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The number of stock options allocated to the pool is generally 10% of the aggregate number of options included in the annual grant. Options remaining in the pool at the end of the period do not </FONT>
</P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">39 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">
<FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">carry over to the following period. The CEO may not make discretionary grants from the pool to the Company&#146;s executive officers. Stock option grants
from the CEO pool are made one time per month according to an annually pre-determined schedule. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Stock options granted in 2006 vest ratably over four years
and have a 10-year term. As required by the Incentive Plan, the options have an exercise price equal to the closing market price of the Common Stock on the New York Stock Exchange on the trading day immediately preceding the date of grant. As
discussed elsewhere in this proxy statement, we are proposing that our stockholders approve changes to the Incentive Plan at this year&#146;s annual meeting, including the way the exercise price of stock options is determined. If the changes are
approved, the exercise price of stock options would be set as the closing price of our Common Stock on the New York Stock Exchange on the grant date. These changes are described in the response to the next question below and in Proposal No.&nbsp;3
beginning on page 62 of this proxy statement. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">See Column (f)&nbsp;of the Summary Compensation Table, Columns (j)&nbsp;through (l)&nbsp;of the Grants of
Plan-Based Awards table, Columns (b)&nbsp;through (f)&nbsp;of the Outstanding Equity Awards table and Columns (b)&nbsp;and (c)&nbsp;of the Option Exercises and Stock Vested table for more information on stock options granted to Mr.&nbsp;Lenny and
the other named executive officers. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Restricted Stock Units.</I>&nbsp;&nbsp;The Committee grants restricted stock unit, or RSU, awards from time to time
as special incentives. RSUs also are awarded to replace compensation forfeited by newly-hired executive officers and key managers of the Company upon leaving a prior employer to join Hershey. Each RSU granted under the Incentive Plan equals a share
of Common Stock. RSUs vest if the grant recipient remains in the Company&#146;s employment for a prescribed period of time. Recipients may elect to receive payment for vested RSUs in cash or in shares of the Company&#146;s Common Stock, net of
applicable taxes. The value of an RSU is based upon the closing price of the Company&#146;s Common Stock on the New York Stock Exchange on the trading day immediately preceding the vesting date. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The Committee is authorized under the Incentive Plan to allocate a pool of RSUs for our CEO to use as recruitment, retention, performance recognition or promotion
awards. The Committee establishes the RSU pool annually. For the past several years, the Committee has allocated 50,000 RSUs to the pool. Such discretionary awards may not be made by the CEO to the Company&#146;s executive officers. RSUs remaining
in the pool at the end of the period do not carry over to the following period. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Retirement Benefits </I></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Executive officers participate in the same defined benefit pension and defined contribution 401(k) plans as do other salaried employees of the Company. Because the
Internal Revenue Code rules do not permit the Company to use base salary and other compensation paid above certain limitations in determining the benefits earned by the executive officers under tax-qualified plans, the Company maintains a
Supplemental Executive Retirement Plan, or SERP, and a Deferred Compensation Plan to provide these and additional benefits. The Company believes that the SERP and Deferred Compensation Plan help attract and retain executive talent, as similar plans
are often components of the executive compensation programs within our high-performing financial peer group. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">We redesigned our retirement plans in 2006 to
maintain competitive retirement benefits while reducing future Company pension costs. The new program, which took effect January&nbsp;1, 2007, includes a higher matching contribution under our 401(k) Plan to encourage and support retirement savings,
a modified defined benefit pension plan that provides future benefits at a </FONT>
</P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">40 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">


 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">
<FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">reduced rate and is closed for new hires beginning in 2007, and a Company-provided core contribution into the 401(k) Plan and increased match for new hires.
No new participants may be added to the existing SERP and benefits for those in the SERP are generally reduced under the new program. Contributions to the Deferred Compensation Plan will be adjusted to reflect the new program. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">See the Pension Benefits table and accompanying narrative beginning on page 52 and the Non-Qualified Deferred Compensation table and accompanying narrative beginning on
page 54 for more information regarding the SERP and retirement benefits. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Executive Perquisites </I></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Executive perquisites are kept by the Committee to a minimal level and do not play a significant role in executive compensation. See Column (i)&nbsp;of the Summary
Compensation Table for information regarding the perquisites received by our named executive officers. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Mr.&nbsp;Lenny and the other named executive
officers are eligible to participate in our Gift Matching Program on the same basis as other employees and retirees or their spouses. Through the Gift Matching Program we match contributions made to one or more accredited colleges or universities on
a dollar-for-dollar basis up to a maximum aggregate contribution of $5,000 annually. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Employment Agreements </I></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">We have not entered into employment agreements with any named executive officer other than Mr.&nbsp;Lenny. We entered into the employment agreement with Mr.&nbsp;Lenny
in connection with his recruitment to the Company in 2001. Our willingness to enter into an employment agreement with Mr.&nbsp;Lenny was instrumental in our ability to attract him to Hershey, and it is an important part of our overall current
compensation and incentive program for him. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">We provide an Executive Benefits Protection Plan, or EBPP, for the named executive officers and other key
management personnel. The terms of the plan generally provide that in the event the executive&#146;s employment with the Company terminates within two years after a &#147;change in control&#148; of the Company, the executive is entitled to certain
severance payments and benefits. The EBPP is intended to help us attract and retain qualified management employees and maintain a stable work environment in connection with a change in control. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Effective December&nbsp;29, 2006, our Board of Directors approved amendments to the EBPP that generally reduced benefits to more closely align them with the benchmark of
our high-performing financial peer group. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Our Board also approved amendments to Mr.&nbsp;Lenny&#146;s employment agreement to delete the provision
regarding a maximum annual bonus under the AIP, and conform to the benefit changes in the SERP and Deferred Compensation Plan. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">See the discussion
beginning on page 56 for information regarding potential payments due to the named executive officers in the event of termination of employment or a change in control. </FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">41 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Have there been any other actions with respect to executive compensation since the end of 2006? </B></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">As described in Proposal No.&nbsp;3, the Board has presented an amendment and restatement of our Incentive Plan for stockholder approval. If the amended plan, renamed
the &#147;Equity and Incentive Compensation Plan,&#148; is approved, among other things, all of our incentive programs will be consolidated under one plan and the exercise price for all options granted to our named executive officers in 2007 will be
equal to the closing price on the grant date. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">On February&nbsp;12, 2007, the Committee approved 2007 base salaries, 2007 AIP target levels, and contingent
target grants of PSUs under the Incentive Plan for the 2007-2009 performance cycle for our executive officers other than Mr.&nbsp;Lenny. On February&nbsp;13, 2007, the Committee made a recommendation to the independent directors as a group regarding
Mr.&nbsp;Lenny&#146;s 2007 base salary, a contingent target maximum grant for the 2007 AIP, and a contingent target grant of PSUs under the Incentive Plan for the 2007-2009 performance cycle. The independent directors as a group approved the
Committee&#146;s recommendation on February&nbsp;13, 2007. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px;padding-bottom:3px;line-height:95%; vertical-align:top"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">For 2007, the base salaries for
Mr.&nbsp;Lenny, Ms.&nbsp;Arline and Mr.&nbsp;Hernquist were not increased above their 2006 levels in light of the Company&#146;s 2006 financial performance. Mr.&nbsp;Bilbrey&#146;s base salary for 2007 was increased to $400,000 to close the gap
between his former base salary and the 50</FONT><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1" COLOR="#000000"><SUP>th</SUP></FONT><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2" COLOR="#000000"> and 75</FONT><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1"
COLOR="#000000"><SUP>th</SUP></FONT><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2" COLOR="#000000"> percentile of the size-adjusted primary peer group and in comparison to other executive officers. Annual and long-term incentive targets for Mr.&nbsp;Lenny,
Ms.&nbsp;Arline, Mr.&nbsp;Bilbrey and Mr.&nbsp;Hernquist were not increased for 2007. Mr.&nbsp;West&#146;s salary, bonus and long-term targets were adjusted in connection with his promotion to Executive Vice President, Chief Operating Officer of the
Company, as discussed below. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">In establishing the 2007 AIP, the Committee determined that the final AIP award earned by Mr.&nbsp;Lenny and our other named
executive officers will be based in full upon achievement of corporate financial objectives. Achievement of individual performance objectives will not be a factor in determining these AIP payments. We made this change to focus our executive
officers&#146; efforts on achievement of quantifiable corporate performance measures in keeping with our &#147;pay-for-performance&#148; compensation philosophy. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman"
SIZE="2">The performance measures and weighting for the 2007 AIP are the same as the 2006 AIP: 40% based on growth in net sales, 40% based on growth in EPS and 20% based on improvement in EBIT margin. The targets for 2007 are centered around the
Company&#146;s publicly-announced financial expectations for 2007: net sales growth of 3% to 4%&nbsp;per year, minimal improvement in EBIT margin and a 7% to 9% increase in EPS. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The Committee also made changes with respect to the performance objectives applicable to the 2007-2009 PSU award. The performance objectives for the 2007-2009 performance cycle are (i)&nbsp;the Company&#146;s
three-year compound annual growth in EPS measured against an internal target based on the Company&#146;s long-term financial goal of 9% to 11% annual growth and (ii)&nbsp;the Company&#146;s total stockholder return, or TSR, over the three-year
period measured against the TSR of the high-performing financial peer group. In making the change to add TSR as a performance measure, the Committee&#146;s intent is to more directly align the long-term incentive compensation attributable to this
PSU award to the returns obtained by our stockholders over the performance period. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The Committee customarily grants stock options to executive officers
and various other management and professional employees in February of each year, two to three weeks after the release of fourth quarter and full-year results that occurs in late January. In February 2007, the Committee elected to delay the grant of
stock options until after the 2007 annual meeting of </FONT>
</P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">42 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">


 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">
<FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">stockholders, when stockholders will be asked to vote on the amended and restated Incentive Plan. It is anticipated that the 2007 stock option grant will be
made shortly after the annual meeting and that in 2008, the Company will return to making stock option grants in February. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Have there been any changes
to the named executive officers since the end of 2006? </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">As announced on January&nbsp;24, 2007, the Board elected David J. West to the position of
Executive Vice President, Chief Operating Officer. Mr.&nbsp;West&#146;s annual base salary, effective January&nbsp;1, 2007, was adjusted by the Committee in February 2007 to $650,000 and his annual and long-term incentive targets were adjusted to
competitive market levels based upon input from Towers Perrin. We added the position of Executive Vice President, Chief Operating Officer to ensure that we have the breadth of executive leadership in place both to pursue Hershey&#146;s strategic
growth opportunities and to deliver on marketplace and financial expectations. Mr.&nbsp;West will also continue to hold the position of Chief Financial Officer until his successor in that position is elected. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>In what other ways do we align the interests of executive officers with the interests of stockholders? </B></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The Company believes that requiring executive officers to hold significant amounts of our Common Stock strengthens the alignment of the executive officers with the
interest of stockholders and promotes achievement of long-term business objectives. We have had executive stock ownership requirements for well over 20 years. In August 2006, these ownership requirements were modified based upon external market
comparisons provided by Towers Perrin. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Executive and appointed officers are required to accumulate the minimum number of shares to meet their stock
ownership level within five years of their election or appointment. For purposes of this requirement, &#147;shares&#148; include shares of our Common Stock that are owned by the officer as well as vested RSUs and PSUs that have been deferred by the
officer as common stock units under our Deferred Compensation Plan. Minimum stockholding requirements for executive and appointed officers range from two to five times base salary. The dollar value of shares which must be acquired and held equals a
multiple of the individual executive&#146;s base salary. The number of shares to be held is updated whenever a change in base salary occurs. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="84%" BORDER="0" ALIGN="center">

<TR>
<TD WIDTH="51%"></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" WIDTH="3%"></TD>
<TD WIDTH="46%"></TD></TR>
<TR>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM:1px solid #000000"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Position</B></FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM:1px solid #000000"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" ALIGN="center" STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM:1px solid #000000"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Stock Ownership Level</B></FONT></TD></TR>
<TR BGCOLOR="#cceeff">
<TD VALIGN="top"> <P STYLE="margin-left:1.00em; text-indent:-1.00em"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">CEO</FONT></P></TD>

</TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Failure to reach the minimum within the five-year period results in a notification letter to the executive, with a
copy to the CEO, and a requirement that future stock option exercises be settled by retaining at least 50% of the shares of Common Stock received until the minimum ownership level is reached. The Committee receives an annual summary of each
individual officer&#146;s ownership status to monitor compliance. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">As of February&nbsp;20, 2007, the record date for the annual meeting, the value of
Common Stock or deferred PSUs owned by Mr.&nbsp;Lenny exceeded five times his base salary. </FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">43 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>
<A NAME="toc67977_15"></A>Compensation Committee Report </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>To Our Stockholders: </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">We have reviewed and discussed with management the Compensation Discussion and Analysis, beginning on page 33. Based on that review and discussion, we have recommended to the Board of Directors that the Compensation
Discussion and Analysis be included in this proxy statement. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Submitted by the Compensation and Executive Organization Committee of the Board of Directors:
</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:54%; text-indent:-2%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Robert H. Campbell, Chair </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:54%; text-indent:-2%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Robert F. Cavanaugh </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:54%; text-indent:-2%"><FONT

members of the Board of Directors who are not members of the Compensation and Executive Organization Committee join in the Compensation Committee Report with respect to the approval of Mr.&nbsp;Lenny&#146;s compensation: </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:54%; text-indent:-2%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Jon A. Boscia </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:54%; text-indent:-2%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman"

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">44 </FONT></P>

using the methodology for determining &#147;total compensation&#148; provided by the SEC. We refer to these five executive officers as our named executive officers. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT

<TD VALIGN="bottom" STYLE="BORDER-TOP:1px solid #000000; BORDER-RIGHT:1px solid #000000; BORDER-BOTTOM:1px solid #000000"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

<TD VALIGN="bottom" ALIGN="center" STYLE="BORDER-TOP:1px solid #000000; BORDER-RIGHT:1px solid #000000; BORDER-BOTTOM:1px solid #000000; padding-right:8px"> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman"
SIZE="1"><B>Total</B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:1px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1"><B>($)</B></FONT></P></TD></TR>

<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">


<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:1px; margin-left:0%">
<FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">cycle appear in Columns (g)&nbsp;and (l)&nbsp;of the Grants of Plan-Based Awards table on page 47. The number of shares acquired and value received in 2006
with respect to PSU awards made in 2004 appear in Columns (d)&nbsp;and (e)&nbsp;of the Option Exercises and Stock Vested table. For Ms. Arline, Mr. Bilbrey and Mr. Hernquist, Column (e) also includes the dollar amount recognized as expense for
financial statement purposes in 2006 as a result of prior year RSU awards. The unvested portion of these RSU awards is included in the amounts presented in Columns (g) and (h) of the Outstanding Equity Awards table. The number of shares acquired and
value received in 2006 by these three executives with respect to RSU awards that vested in 2006 is included in Columns (d) and (e) of the Option Exercises and Stock Vested table. </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P
STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">(4)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">Column (f)&nbsp;presents the dollar amount recognized as expense by the Company for financial statement reporting purposes with respect to stock options held by the executive during
2006 and does not reflect the value of shares actually received during 2006 or which may be received in the future with respect to such stock options. As indicated on the Option Exercises and Stock Vested table, Mr.&nbsp;Lenny, Mr.&nbsp;West,
Ms.&nbsp;Arline and Mr.&nbsp;Bilbrey did not receive cash or stock from the exercise of any option awards in 2006. The assumptions we made to determine these amounts are set forth in note 15 to the Company&#146;s consolidated financial statements
included in our 2006 Annual Report to Stockholders that accompanies this proxy statement. The number and grant date fair value of stock options granted to each named executive officer during 2006 appears in Columns (j)&nbsp;and (l)&nbsp;of the
Grants of Plan-Based Awards table on page&nbsp;47. The amounts realized in 2006 by Mr.&nbsp;Hernquist with respect to options exercised appears in Columns (b)&nbsp;and (c)&nbsp;of the Option Exercises and Stock Vested table.
</FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">(5)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">As shown in Column (g)&nbsp;and discussed in the Compensation Discussion and Analysis, no payments were awarded to any of the named executive officers in 2006 under AIP, our Annual
Incentive Program. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">(6)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">Column (h)&nbsp;reflects the change in the actuarial present value of the named executive officer&#146;s pension benefit under the Company&#146;s tax-qualified pension plan and the
Supplemental Executive Retirement Plan, or SERP, from the pension plan measurement date used in preparing the 2005 audited financial statements to the pension plan measurement date used for the 2006 audited financial statements, determined using the
interest rate and mortality rate assumptions consistent with those used in our 2006 audited financial statements. The named executive officers also participate in our non-qualified Deferred Compensation Plan under which amounts deferred are credited
with &#147;earnings&#148; based on the performance of indices based on the mutual funds and other investment options available under our 401(k) Plan. No portion of the &#147;earnings&#148; credited during 2006 was &#147;above market&#148; or
&#147;preferential.&#148; Consequently, no Deferred Compensation Plan earnings are included in amounts reported in Column (h)&nbsp;above. See the Pension Benefits table and Deferred Compensation table for more information on the benefits payable
under the qualified pension plan, SERP and Deferred Compensation Plan to the named executive officers. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">(9)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">At the time Mr.&nbsp;Bilbrey joined Hershey in 2003, we agreed to provide certain relocation assistance in connection with the sale of his residence and move to the Hershey,
Pennsylvania area. Mr.&nbsp;Bilbrey sold his prior residence during 2006 and received a payment of $150,000 to partially offset the loss on sale of his prior residence, $69,675 for moving, storage and closing costs and $156,834 for reimbursement of
certain taxes related to his relocation. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>
<A NAME="toc67977_17"></A>Grants of Plan-Based Awards </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The following table and explanatory footnotes provide information with regard to the potential
cash award that might have been earned during 2006 under our Annual Incentive Program, or AIP, and with respect to each PSU, stock option and restricted stock unit granted to each named executive officer during 2006. No amounts were earned under the
AIP during 2006. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Grants of Plan-Based Awards </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>2006 </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

<TD COLSPAN="1" NOWRAP VALIGN="bottom" STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT:1px solid #000000; BORDER-BOTTOM:1px solid #000000"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM:1px solid #000000"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="right" COLSPAN="1" VALIGN="bottom" STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM:1px solid #000000"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">294,000</FONT></TD>
<TD COLSPAN="1" NOWRAP VALIGN="bottom" STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT:1px solid #000000; BORDER-BOTTOM:1px solid #000000"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM:1px solid #000000"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="right" COLSPAN="1" VALIGN="bottom" STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM:1px solid #000000"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">551,250</FONT></TD>
<TD COLSPAN="1" NOWRAP VALIGN="bottom" STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT:1px solid #000000; BORDER-BOTTOM:1px solid #000000"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM:1px solid #000000"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="right" COLSPAN="1" VALIGN="bottom" STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM:1px solid #000000"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">0</FONT></TD>
<TD COLSPAN="1" NOWRAP VALIGN="bottom" STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT:1px solid #000000; BORDER-BOTTOM:1px solid #000000; padding-right:8px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD></TR>
</TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">(1)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">All awards presented were made in accordance with the Company&#146;s stockholder-approved Incentive Plan. Dates listed in Column (b) represent the Grant Date for PSUs reflected in
Columns (f), (g) and (h) and the stock options listed in Column (j). </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">(2)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">As was discussed in the Compensation Discussion and Analysis and as presented in the final column of the Addendum to Grants of Plan-Based Awards Table, no AIP payments were earned
by or paid to the named executive officers for 2006 performance. The amounts shown in Columns (c), (d) and (e) represent the threshold, target and maximum potential amounts that might have been payable based on the AIP targets approved for the named
executive officers in February 2006. The amount for Mr. Lenny reflects a maximum contingent award made in February 2006 under the provisions of our AIP. The maximum contingent award is intended to ensure that the amount of AIP that might have been
paid to him would qualify as tax-deductible performance-based compensation under section 162(m) of the Internal Revenue Code. Although no amount was awarded to Mr. Lenny for 2006 performance, an award would have been based on factors similar to
those applied to other named executive officers. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">47 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">


<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">For the named executive officers other than Mr. Lenny, the threshold amount is the amount that would have been payable had the minimum level of performance been achieved. Target is
the amount payable had the business performance and individual objectives been achieved at 100%. The maximum amount reflects the highest amount payable for maximum performance of 200% of business performance objectives and 150% of individual
performance objectives. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">(3)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">The number of units presented in Columns (f), (g)&nbsp;and (h)&nbsp;represent PSUs granted for the 2006-2008 cycle. Each PSU represents the value of one share of our Common Stock.
The number of PSUs earned will depend upon achievement against two equally-weighted performance measures: the Company&#146;s three-year compound annual growth in EPS as compared to the median three-year compound annual growth in EPS of our
high-performing financial peer group and our cumulative, three-year improvement in E-ROIC against our internal benchmark. The minimum award is payable at achievement of 10% of target, as shown in Column (f)&nbsp;and the maximum award is payable at
achievement of 250% of target as shown in Column (h). The actual number of PSUs earned by any of the named executive officers will not be known until the conclusion of the three-year cycle on December&nbsp;31, 2008. PSUs earned from the 2006-2008
performance cycle will be paid only in shares of our Common Stock. More information regarding PSUs and the 2006 award can be found in the Compensation Discussion and Analysis and the following Outstanding Equity Awards table.
</FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">(4)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">The number of options awarded to each named executive officer was calculated as one-half of the executive&#146;s long-term incentive target percentage times his or her 2006 base
salary divided by the Black-Scholes value of $15.05 for each option. The Black-Scholes value is based on the $52.30 exercise price for these options determined as the closing price of the Company&#146;s Common Stock on February&nbsp;15, 2006, the
trading day immediately preceding the grant date, as required by the Incentive Plan. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:3%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">All option awards granted by the Company
have a 10-year term, subject to earlier expiration in the event of termination of employment, and vest in 25% increments over four years, beginning on the first anniversary of the grant date, subject to acceleration in the event of a change in
control of the Company and continued vesting in the event of retirement, death or disability. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:3%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">More information regarding stock options and
the 2006 award can be found in the Compensation Discussion and Analysis and the following Outstanding Equity Awards table. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">(5)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">These columns present the exercise price for each option award based upon the closing price of the Company&#146;s Common Stock on the New York Stock Exchange on the trading day
immediately preceding the grant date shown in Column (b), as required by the Incentive Plan and, as required by the SEC rules, the closing price on the grant date. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P
STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">(6)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">Column (l)&nbsp;presents the aggregate grant date fair value of the target number of PSUs reported in Column (g)&nbsp;and the stock options reported in Column (j), as determined in
accordance with SFAS No.&nbsp;123R. The assumptions used in determining these amounts are set forth in note 15 to the Company&#146;s consolidated financial statements included in our 2006 Annual Report to Stockholders that accompanies this proxy
statement. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">49 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">


<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">(1)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">Columns (b)&nbsp;through (f)&nbsp;present information about stock options awarded to each named executive officer under the Incentive Plan. Except as otherwise described in these
footnotes, each option vests as to 25% of the shares on each of the first four anniversaries of the grant date, subject to earlier vesting in the event of a change in control. Upon termination of employment, vested options must be exercised and
unvested options are cancelled, except in the case of retirement, death or disability in which case the options continue to vest as scheduled and may be exercised for up to five years after termination of employment. If termination occurs within two
years after a change in control for any reason other than for cause or by the executive without good reason, vested options may be exercised for one year after termination. No option may be exercised after its expiration date.
</FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">(2)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">Options listed in Column (b)&nbsp;are vested and may be exercised by the executive at any time subject to the terms of the stock option. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P
STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">(3)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">Options listed in Column (c)&nbsp;have not vested as of December&nbsp;31, 2006. The following table provides information with respect to the dates on which these options are
scheduled to vest, subject to continued employment (or retirement, death or disability) and to acceleration in the event of a change in control. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

<TD COLSPAN="1" NOWRAP VALIGN="bottom" STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT:1px solid #000000; BORDER-BOTTOM:1px solid #000000; padding-right:8px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1"><B>&nbsp;</B></FONT></TD></TR>
</TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P STYLE="line-height:80%; vertical-align:top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">For Mr.&nbsp;Lenny, Column (g)&nbsp;includes PSUs earned with respect to the 2003-2005 performance cycle which vested on
his 55<SUP>th</SUP> birthday, January&nbsp;5, 2007. Mr.&nbsp;Lenny is not eligible to receive payment for the 2003-2005 performance cycle PSUs until his retirement or during first quarter 2009, whichever comes earlier. </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE>

will vest on her 55<SUP>th</SUP> birthday, in March 2007. Ms.&nbsp;Arline is not eligible to receive payment for the 2003-2005 performance cycle PSUs until her retirement or during first quarter 2009, whichever comes earlier. For Ms.&nbsp;Arline,

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>

<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">(5)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">Column (h) contains the value of the PSUs and RSUs reported in Column (g) using a price per share of our Common Stock of $49.80, the closing price of our Common Stock on the New
York Stock Exchange on December 29, 2006, the last trading day of 2006. Column (h) also includes accrued dividends and interest through December 31, 2006 on the PSUs and RSUs included in Column (g). Accrued dividends and interest will be paid in
cash upon vesting. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">(6)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">For each named executive officer, the first number in Column (i)&nbsp;is the target number of PSUs awarded for the 2006-2008 performance cycle and the second number is the target
number of PSUs awarded for the 2005-2007 performance cycle. The number of PSUs earned, if any, will be determined at the end of the performance cycle. The 2006-2008 cycle ends on December&nbsp;31, 2008. The 2005-2007 cycle ends on December&nbsp;31,
2007. Based on progress to date against goals, the Company is accruing expense for these two performance cycles at levels that are above threshold, but below the target goals set at the start of the three-year performance cycles. The actual number
of PSUs earned may be more or less than the amount reflected in Column (i). </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

York Stock Exchange on December&nbsp;29, 2006, the last trading day of 2006. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>

our Board in the case of Mr.&nbsp;Lenny, to be earned. These PSUs were paid in February 2007. For Mr.&nbsp;Lenny, Column (d)&nbsp;also includes a special grant of 80,000 PSUs made in 2004 for a cycle that ended December&nbsp;31, 2006 that were
determined by the independent directors to be earned and were paid in February 2007. In accordance with the PSU award, each PSU represents one share of our Common Stock valued at $50.37, the December 2006 average closing price of our Common Stock.
For Ms. Arline, Mr. Bilbrey and Mr.&nbsp;Hernquist, Column (d) also includes the number of RSUs that vested in 2006 as a result of prior year awards. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

RSU awards granted to them in 2005. Required tax withholdings were deducted from </FONT>
</P></TD></TR></TABLE>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">51 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">


<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:1px; margin-left:0%">
<FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">the share payment, following which Ms.&nbsp;Arline and Mr.&nbsp;Bilbrey each received 883 shares. On the vesting date of these RSUs, Ms.&nbsp;Arline and
Mr.&nbsp;Bilbrey each received a cash payment of $1,225, equivalent to dividends that would have been earned on these RSUs during the vesting period. Column (e)&nbsp;reflects the market value of the 1,250 shares on the vesting date and the cash
equivalent of dividends paid on the vesting date. </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">(5)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">Mr.&nbsp;Bilbrey chose to defer receipt of the PSUs that were payable to him as a result of the 2004-2006 PSU cycle. The gross number of shares payable to him, 11,792, was reduced
by required tax withholdings, and the net amount, 11,471 shares, was deferred. Mr.&nbsp;Bilbrey elected to receive these deferred shares in a single payment upon retirement or separation from the Company. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P
STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">(6)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">Mr.&nbsp;Hernquist chose to defer receipt of the PSUs that were payable to him from the 2004-2006 PSU cycle. The gross number of shares payable to him, 13,024, was reduced by
required tax withholdings, and the net amount, 12,683 shares, was deferred. Mr.&nbsp;Hernquist elected to receive these deferred shares in a single payment in 2009. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P
STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">(7)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">On February&nbsp;28, 2006, 2,500 RSUs awarded to Mr.&nbsp;Hernquist in 2005 vested. On June&nbsp;16, 2006 an additional 1,250 RSUs awarded to Mr.&nbsp;Hernquist in 2004 vested. For
both of these awards, Mr.&nbsp;Hernquist elected to receive immediate payment upon vesting in cash rather than in shares. The value of the RSUs paid to Mr.&nbsp;Hernquist was based on the closing price of the Company&#146;s Common Stock on the
trading days immediately preceding the vesting dates. Required tax withholdings were deducted from the payments, and a total of $136,726 was distributed to him. In addition, Mr.&nbsp;Hernquist received cash payments equivalent to dividends that
would have been earned on these RSUs during the vesting periods totaling $4,713. Column (e)&nbsp;reflects the market value of the 3,750 shares realized by Mr.&nbsp;Hernquist on the vesting date and the cash equivalent of dividends paid on the
vesting date. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Pension Benefits </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Each of
the named executive officers was eligible in 2006 to participate in our tax-qualified defined benefit pension plan and our non-qualified SERP. The combined plans were designed to provide a benefit on retirement at or after reaching age 60 based on a
joint and survivor annuity equal to 55% of final average compensation for an executive officer with 15 or more years of service (reduced pro rata for each year of service under 15). With the exception of Mr.&nbsp;Lenny, whose eligibility for a SERP
benefit is described below, no benefit is payable under the SERP if the executive officer terminates employment prior to age 55 or if he or she does not have ten years of service with the Company, five of which were in a SERP-eligible position. As
of December&nbsp;31, 2006, none of the named executive officers had reached age 55. Benefits in our tax-qualified plan vest after five years of service. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman"
SIZE="2">Final average compensation is calculated as the sum of the highest annual average of base salary paid or accrued over any consecutive 36-month period, and the highest annual average of AIP paid or accrued over any five consecutive calendar
years, during the most recent ten years. The benefit accrued under the SERP is payable upon retirement in a lump sum or life annuity with 50% benefit continuation to the participant&#146;s surviving spouse. If selected by the participant, the lump
sum is equal to the actuarial present value of the joint and survivor pension earned, reduced by the lump sum value of the benefits to be paid under the tax-qualified pension plan and the value of the executive&#146;s Social Security benefits. If
the executive officer terminates employment after age 55 but before age 60, the benefit is reduced at a rate of 5%&nbsp;per year for the period until the executive would have turned 60. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px;padding-bottom:3px;line-height:95%; vertical-align:top"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Our employment agreement with Mr.&nbsp;Lenny contains special provisions relating to his vesting and the
calculation of his benefit under the SERP in recognition of the impact a mid-career change in jobs has on the long-term accrual of retirement benefits. Under the employment agreement, Mr.&nbsp;Lenny is fully vested in his accrued SERP benefit;
however, he would have forfeited his SERP benefit had we terminated his employment for cause or had he terminated his employment without &#147;good reason&#148; before his 55</FONT><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1"
COLOR="#000000"><SUP>th</SUP></FONT><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2" COLOR="#000000"> birthday on January 5, 2007. Additionally, he was effectively credited with two years of service for each year of service from his hire date through his
55</FONT><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1" COLOR="#000000"><SUP>th</SUP></FONT><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2" COLOR="#000000"> birthday. He will earn a benefit at an annual rate of 3.5% from age 55 to age 60. This formula produces a
benefit at age 55 based on 37.5% of his final average compensation and of 55% of his final average compensation at his 60</FONT><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1" COLOR="#000000"><SUP>th</SUP></FONT><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"
COLOR="#000000"> birthday. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">52 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The following table and explanatory footnotes provide information regarding the present value of benefits accrued
under the tax-qualified defined benefit pension plan and the SERP for each named executive officer as of December&nbsp;31, 2006. The amounts shown for the SERP reflect the reduction for the present value of the benefits under the tax-qualified
pension plan and Social Security benefits. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>

<TD VALIGN="bottom" STYLE="BORDER-LEFT:1px solid #000000"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The Hershey Retirement Plan</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman"

<TD ALIGN="right" COLSPAN="1" VALIGN="top"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">93,646</FONT></TD>
<TD COLSPAN="1" NOWRAP VALIGN="top" STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT:1px solid #000000"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="top" ALIGN="center" STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT:1px solid #000000; padding-right:8px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#151;</FONT></TD></TR>
<TR>
<TD VALIGN="top" STYLE="BORDER-LEFT:1px solid #000000; padding-left:8px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" STYLE="BORDER-LEFT:1px solid #000000"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
