 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">53 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:3%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">During 2006, the SERP was amended to provide that no new individual will participate in the SERP after
October&nbsp;2, 2006 and the benefits under the plan were amended effective January&nbsp;1, 2007. The 2006 amendment reduces the final lump sum for executives who have reached age 50 as of January&nbsp;1, 2007 by 10% (Mr. Lenny, Ms.&nbsp;Arline and
Mr.&nbsp;Bilbrey), and by 20% for those not age 50 on that date (Mr. West and Mr. Hernquist). Under the amended plan, no benefit is payable under the SERP if the executive officer (other than Mr.&nbsp;Lenny, who was age 55 on January&nbsp;5, 2007)
terminates employment prior to age 55 or if he or she does not have five years of service credited under the SERP. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:3%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">As a result of the
amendment, final average compensation is based on the average of the highest three calendar years&#146; base salary received over the last five years of employment plus the average of the highest three calendar year awards under the AIP over the
last five years of employment. The benefit accrued under the SERP as of January&nbsp;1, 2007 is payable only in a lump sum following retirement. Other provisions of the SERP were not impacted by the restatement. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:3%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">The following table shows how the amendment affected each named executive officer&#146;s accrued benefit: </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="93%" BORDER="0" ALIGN="center">

<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">(2)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">Our employment agreement with Mr.&nbsp;Lenny provides for more rapid accrual under the SERP. His 5.8 years of service are equivalent to 10.2 years of service under the SERP.
</FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>
<A NAME="toc67977_21"></A>Non-Qualified Deferred Compensation </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Our named executive officers are eligible to participate in The Hershey Company Deferred
Compensation Plan. The Deferred Compensation Plan is a non-qualified plan that permits participants to defer receipt of compensation otherwise payable to them. The Deferred Compensation Plan is intended to secure the goodwill and loyalty of
participants by enabling them to defer compensation when the participant deems it to be beneficial to do so and by providing a vehicle for the Company to provide on a non-qualified basis contributions which could not be made on the
participant&#146;s behalf to the tax-qualified 401(k) Plan. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Our named executive officers may elect to defer payments to be received as a result of AIP,
PSU and RSU awards (but not stock options). Amounts deferred are credited to the participant&#146;s account under the Plan. As of January&nbsp;1, 2007, participants may defer benefits payable under the SERP. Also, beginning on January&nbsp;1, 2007,
we will credit the named executive officers&#146; deferred compensation accounts with the amount of employer matching contributions that exceed the limits established by the Internal Revenue Service for contribution to the 401(k) Plan. Amounts
deferred are fully vested and will be paid at a future date or at termination of employment, as the participant may elect. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Payments are distributed in a
lump sum or in annual installments of up to ten years. Effective January&nbsp;1, 2007, distributions may be paid in annual installments of up to 15 years. All amounts are payable in a lump sum following a change in control. All elections and
payments under the </FONT>
</P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">54 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">


 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">
<FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Plan are subject to compliance with section 409A of the Internal Revenue Code which may limit elections and require a delay in payment of benefits in certain
circumstances. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">While deferred, amounts are credited with &#147;earnings&#148; as if they were invested as the participant elects in one or more investment
options available under the Plan. The investment options under the Plan consist of investment in shares of our Common Stock or in mutual funds or other investments available to participants in our 401(k) Plan. The participants&#146; accounts under
the Plan will be adjusted from time to time, up or down, depending upon performance of the investment options elected. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The following table sets forth
information relating to the activity in the Deferred Compensation Plan accounts of the named executive officers during 2006 and the aggregate balance of the accounts as of December&nbsp;31, 2006. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Non-Qualified Deferred Compensation </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman"
SIZE="2"><B>2006 </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

<TD COLSPAN="1" NOWRAP VALIGN="bottom" STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT:1px solid #000000; BORDER-BOTTOM:1px solid #000000; padding-right:8px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD></TR>

<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">(4)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">In 2006, Mr.&nbsp;West received payment for 18,770 previously deferred RSUs and the accumulated earnings on those RSUs since the date of deferral. These RSUs were granted on
May&nbsp;21, 2001 and vested on January&nbsp;2, 2002. At the time of vesting, Mr.&nbsp;West elected to defer receipt of these units until January 2006. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>
<A NAME="toc67977_22"></A>Potential Payments Upon Termination or Change in Control </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">We have entered into an employment agreement with Mr.&nbsp;Lenny
and maintain plans covering our executive officers that will require us to provide incremental compensation in the event of involuntary termination of employment or a change in control. We describe these obligations below. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Overview </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">We entered into an employment agreement with
Mr.&nbsp;Lenny at the time he joined Hershey in 2001. The agreement has a term of three years and renews daily. The agreement provides for Mr.&nbsp;Lenny&#146;s employment as our Chairman of the Board, President and Chief Executive Officer, contains
provisions relating to his responsibilities, compensation, confidentiality and non-solicitation commitments and agreements, and payments, if any, to be made to him upon termination of employment. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Mr.&nbsp;Lenny and our other named executive officers participate in the EBPP, as amended effective December&nbsp;29, 2006. The plan is intended to help us attract and
retain qualified management employees and maintain a stable work environment by making a provision for the protection of covered executives in connection with a change in control of Hershey or termination of employment under certain circumstances.
</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Each of our named executive officers also has entered into a participation agreement in connection with the receipt of long-term incentive compensation
awards such as stock options and PSUs. The participation agreement obligates the executive officer to not disclose or misuse our confidential and proprietary information. In addition, any executive officer eligible to participate in the SERP agrees
that while employed, and for three years after termination of employment for any reason, he or she will not join or otherwise become involved with a domestic or worldwide business that competes in any of our primary product lines. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Termination of employment and a change in control also impact PSUs, RSUs and stock option awards we have made, as well as benefits payable under our employee benefit
plans. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The following discussion takes each termination of employment situation &#150; voluntary resignation, discharge for cause, death, disability,
discharge without cause, and resignation for good reason &#150; and a change in control of the Company, and describes the additional amounts, if any, that the Company would pay or provide to the named executive officer or the officer&#146;s
beneficiaries as a </FONT>
</P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">56 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">


 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">
<FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">result. The discussion below and the amounts shown reflect certain assumptions we have made in accordance with SEC rules. These assumptions are that the
termination of employment or change in control occurred on December&nbsp;31, 2006 and that the value of a share of our Common Stock on that day was $49.80, the closing price on the New York Stock Exchange on December&nbsp;29, 2006, the last trading
day of 2006. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">In addition, in keeping with SEC rules, the following discussion and amounts do not include payments and benefits which are not enhanced by
the termination of employment or change in control. These payments and benefits include: </FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">benefits accrued under the Company&#146;s tax-qualified 401(k) Plan and pension plan in which all employees participate; </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P
STYLE="font-size:2px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">accrued vacation pay, health plan continuation and other similar amounts payable when employment terminates under programs applicable to the Company&#146;s salaried
employees generally; </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:2px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">vested benefits accrued under the SERP and account balances held under the Deferred Compensation Plan as described above beginning on pages 52 and 54; and
</FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:2px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">stock options which have vested and become exercisable prior to the employment termination or change in control. </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The payments and benefits described in the four bullet points above are referred to in the following discussion as the executive officer&#146;s &#147;vested
benefits.&#148; </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Voluntary Resignation </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">We are not
obligated to pay amounts over and above vested benefits to a named executive officer who voluntarily resigns. Vested stock options may not be exercised after the named executive officer&#146;s resignation date. Mr. Lenny&#146;s SERP benefit would
have been subject to forfeiture if he voluntarily resigned on December 31, 2006. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Discharge for Cause </I></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">If we terminate a named executive officer&#146;s employment for &#147;cause,&#148; we are not obligated to pay the officer any amounts over and above the vested
benefits. The named executive officer&#146;s right to exercise vested options expires upon discharge for cause, and amounts otherwise payable under the SERP are subject to forfeiture at the Company&#146;s discretion. Had Mr. Lenny&#146;s employment
been terminated for &#147;cause&#148; on December 31, 2006, his SERP benefit would have been forfeited in accordance with his employment agreement. In general, a discharge will be for &#147;cause&#148; if the executive has intentionally failed to
perform his or her duties or engaged in illegal or gross misconduct that harms the Company. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Death or Disability </I></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">If an executive officer other than Mr.&nbsp;Lenny dies and has not met the vesting requirements to be eligible to receive a benefit from the SERP, no benefits are paid.
Except for Mr.&nbsp;Lenny, none of the named executive officers were vested in their SERP benefit as of December&nbsp;31, 2006. No benefits would be paid as of December&nbsp;31, 2006 in the event of the death of any of our named executive officers
other than Mr. Lenny. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">A maximum monthly benefit of $35,000 is provided for our CEO and $25,000 for all other named executive officers in the event of
disability. Disability benefits are payable until age 65. Disability </FONT>
</P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">57 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">
<FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">benefits are offset by other benefits such as Social Security. The maximum amount of the monthly disability payments from all sources assuming disability on
December&nbsp;31, 2006, is set forth in the table below and also shows the additional lump sum SERP amount that would be payable at age 65 due to service credited while disabled, if the executive&#146;s employment had terminated due to disability on
December&nbsp;31, 2006: </FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">Reflects additional lump sum amount of SERP benefit payable at age 65 attributable to vesting and benefit service credited during disability period. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Treatment of Stock Options upon Retirement, Death or Disability </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The
Incentive Plan provides that all vested stock options remain exercisable for five years following termination due to retirement after age 55, death or disability, but not beyond the original term of the option. Options that are not vested at the
time of retirement, death or disability will continue to vest throughout the five-year period following retirement, death or disability according to the original vesting schedule established at the grant date. The following table provides the number
of unvested stock options as of December&nbsp;31, 2006 that would have remained exercisable following death or disability on December&nbsp;31, 2006, and the value of those options based on the excess of the fair market value of our Common Stock on
December&nbsp;31, 2006 over the option exercise price. None of the named executive officers was retirement eligible on December&nbsp;31, 2006. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Treatment of RSUs upon Retirement, Death or Disability </I></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Upon retirement any RSUs that are not vested are forfeited. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">A prorated
portion of any unvested RSUs vests upon death or disability. The prorated number of RSUs is based upon the number of months since the grant date and the date of death or disability divided by the number of months in the vesting period multiplied by
the number of unvested RSUs. The following table summarizes the unvested RSU awards that would have vested on December&nbsp;31, 2006 if the executive&#146;s employment terminated that day due to death or disability. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">Value of shares based on $49.80 stock value on December&nbsp;31, 2006. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman"
SIZE="2"><I>Discharge Not for Cause; Resignation for Good Reason </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Our employment agreement with Mr.&nbsp;Lenny obligates the Company to pay severance
benefits if we terminate his employment for reasons other than for &#147;cause&#148; or if Mr.&nbsp;Lenny resigns for &#147;good reason.&#148; Mr.&nbsp;Lenny will have &#147;good reason&#148; to resign if there is a material breach of the employment
agreement by the Company, including a failure to maintain Mr.&nbsp;Lenny in his current positions, adversely changing his authority or responsibilities, failing to pay or provide agreed-upon compensation and benefits, requiring that he relocate more
than 50 miles from Hershey, Pennsylvania or giving notice to stop the daily renewal of the term of the employment agreement. Mr.&nbsp;Lenny must give the Company notice and an opportunity to cure the breach before resigning for &#147;good
reason.&#148; The severance benefits payable to Mr.&nbsp;Lenny are a lump sum equal to a pro rata AIP award for the year of termination at target plus two times his annual base salary and target AIP award for the year of termination, and
continuation of health and other benefits for two years, subject to reduction for benefits received from a subsequent employer. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">With respect to the named
executive officers other than Mr.&nbsp;Lenny, under the EBPP, we have agreed to pay severance benefits in the form of a two-year paid leave of absence if we terminate the executive officer&#146;s active employment without cause. These benefits are
also payable if the executive officer resigns from active employment for &#147;good reason.&#148; &#147;Good reason&#148; arises under the EBPP if we appoint a new Chief Executive Officer and, during the first two years of his or her tenure, the
executive officer&#146;s position, authority, duties or responsibilities are diminished or base salary is reduced. During the leave of absence, the executive officer&#146;s employment continues, so that he or she will continue to receive a base
salary and to earn, vest or participate in our benefit plans and previously granted stock options and contingent target AIP and PSU awards during the leave of absence period. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">As reflected on the Grants of Plan-Based Awards table, in February 2006 the independent directors approved a maximum contingent AIP award for Mr.&nbsp;Lenny for 2006. A specific AIP </FONT>
</P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">59 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">
<FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">target or target award was not defined by the Committee. For illustrative purposes only, in the following severance and change in control calculations we
have used an AIP target of 125% of salary for Mr.&nbsp;Lenny, and the actual target percent approved by the Committee for the other named executive officers. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman"
SIZE="2">The following table summarizes the amount of severance benefits that would be payable to the named executive officer had his or her employment terminated on December&nbsp;31, 2006, under circumstances entitling the officer to severance
benefits as described above: </FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">(1)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">Reflects amount of medical, dental and vision continuation premiums paid by the Company during salary continuation period. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">In addition, all stock options outstanding at the time of termination of active employment will remain outstanding and continue to vest as if the executive
officer&#146;s employment continued during the two-year leave of absence. The executive officer will not be entitled to receive new stock option, contingent PSU or RSU awards or other awards during the leave of absence. Information with respect to
stock options held by each executive officer as of December&nbsp;31, 2006 appears in the Outstanding Equity Awards table. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Change in Control
</I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Special provisions apply if a change in control occurs. In general, a change in control will occur if the Milton Hershey School Trust no longer owns
voting control of the Company and another person or group acquires 25% or more of the combined voting power of our voting stock, there is an unwelcome change in a majority of the members of our Board, or, if after our stockholders approve a merger
or similar business transaction or a sale of substantially all of our assets, the Milton Hershey School Trust does not own voting control of the merged or acquiring company. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Our employment agreement with Mr.&nbsp;Lenny provides that he is entitled to the benefits of the EBPP if a change in control occurs. The EBPP provides the vesting and payment of the following benefits upon a change in
control to each of the named executive officers: </FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">an AIP payment for the year of the change in control at the greater of target or the estimated payment based on actual performance to the date of the change in
control; </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:2px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">a cash payment equal to the PSU grant for the cycle ending in the year of change in control at the greater of target or actual performance through the date of the
change in control, with each PSU valued at the highest closing price for our Common Stock during the 60 days prior to the change in control; </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:2px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

Cause or Resignation for Good Reason after Change in Control </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">If the named executive officer&#146;s employment is terminated by the Company without
cause or by the executive for good reason within two years after the change in control, we pay severance benefits to assist the executive in transitioning to new employment. &#147;Good reason&#148; for this purpose means diminution of the
executive&#146;s position, authority, duties or responsibilities; a reduction in base salary; the requirement that the executive engage in substantially greater business travel; failure to pay current compensation or to continue in effect short- and
long-term compensation and employee and retirement benefits; or the failure to fund a grantor trust to support payment of amounts under the EBPP. The severance benefits under the EBPP for termination after a change in control consist of: </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; padding-bottom:3px; margin-top:-2px" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"> <P STYLE="line-height:95%; vertical-align:top"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;</FONT></P></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P STYLE="line-height:95%; vertical-align:top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">a lump sum cash payment equal to three (or, if less, the number of full and fractional years from the date of
termination to the executive&#146;s 65</FONT><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1" COLOR="#000000"><SUP>th</SUP></FONT><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2" COLOR="#000000"> birthday, but not less than one) </FONT>
</P></TD></TR></TABLE>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">61 </FONT></P>

<FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">times the executive&#146;s salary and the highest AIP payment earned during the three years preceding the year of the change in control (but not less than
the AIP target for the year of the change in control); </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:2px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">continuation of medical and other benefits for 36 months (or if less, the number of months until the executive attains age 65, but not less than 12 months), or
payment of the value of such benefits if continuation is not permitted under the terms of the applicable plan; </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:2px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">(4)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">Gross-up payment for excise taxes for all named executive officers was determined using a transaction price of $49.80 and an individual tax rate of 40.61%. This payment was
determined assuming all executives were involuntarily terminated on December 31, 2006; deemed to be &#147;disqualified individuals&#148;; and subject to the golden parachute rules under section 280G of the Internal Revenue Code.
</FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>
<A NAME="toc67977_23"></A>PROPOSAL NO. 3 &#150; APPROVAL OF THE EQUITY AND INCENTIVE COMPENSATION PLAN </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>What is the Board proposing? </B></FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The Board is proposing that you approve The Hershey Company Equity and Incentive Compensation Plan. We call this plan the &#147;EICP.&#148; The plan that is the
subject of this proposal is an amendment and restatement of our Key Employee Incentive Plan (we call this plan the &#147;Incentive Plan&#148;), and also a continuation of our Broad Based Stock Option Plan and Broad Based </FONT>
</P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">62 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">


 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">
<FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Annual Incentive Plan (we refer to these plans together as the &#147;Broad Based Plans&#148;) and our Directors&#146; Compensation Plan. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">We have a well-established policy of rewarding results, at all levels of our organization, through our compensation and incentive programs. Our annual incentive programs
are linked to performance measures based on business objectives. We have a history of tying a portion of pay to our long-term stock performance for all employees, not just officers, and for our board members as well. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">We have provided this compensation to our executives and senior management through annual incentive, stock option and performance awards under the Incentive Plan, to
non-executive employees through Company-wide annual incentive and stock option grants under the Broad Based Plans, and to directors through restricted stock unit, Common Stock and deferred stock unit grants under the Directors&#146; Compensation
Plan. Each of these plans was last reviewed and updated in 2002, with the exception of the Broad Based Annual Incentive Plan adopted in 2006. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The
Compensation and Executive Organization Committee of our Board, which we refer to in this Proposal as the &#147;Committee,&#148; and the Board reviewed the Incentive Plan, Broad Based Plans and Directors&#146; Compensation Plan and determined that
to best be able to continue to provide necessary and long-term annual compensation and incentives, these plans should be updated. This updating is reflected in the EICP and includes: </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">amending, restating and renaming the Incentive Plan as the Equity and Incentive Compensation Plan; </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P
STYLE="font-size:2px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">making the EICP a single plan under which grants using shares for compensation and incentive purposes will be made; </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P
STYLE="font-size:2px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">increasing the maximum number of shares of Common Stock available for issuance; and </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P
STYLE="font-size:2px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">adding flexibility for designing compensation and annual and long-term incentive programs and awards. </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The Board approved the EICP at its February&nbsp;13, 2007 meeting, to be effective upon an affirmative vote of a majority of the shares present in person or represented
by proxy at the annual meeting. The vote is needed to satisfy certain regulatory, New York Stock Exchange and tax rules. If the EICP is approved, no further grants will be made under the Broad Based Plans and stock awards paid to our non-employee
directors under the Directors&#146; Compensation Plan will be made through the EICP. If the EICP is not approved, the Incentive Plan, Broad Based Plans and Directors&#146; Compensation Plan will continue in their current forms. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Description of the EICP </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The following paragraphs provide a summary
of the principal features of the EICP, as approved by the Board, and its operation. A copy of the EICP is included in this proxy statement as Appendix&nbsp;B. You should review Appendix B for more information. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>What is the purpose of the EICP? </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The EICP is intended to promote
our success by providing a vehicle under which a variety of cash- or stock-based annual and long-term incentive and other awards can be granted to employees, non-employee directors and certain service providers upon whom the successful conduct of
our business is dependent. These awards are intended to help us attract top talent and to motivate </FONT>
</P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">63 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">
<FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">the recipients to continue and increase their efforts on behalf of the Company and remain in the service of the Company. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>What types of awards can be granted under the EICP? </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The EICP will
continue to provide for the granting of annual incentive awards and stock options, stock appreciation rights, or SARs, restricted stock unit and performance stock unit awards. These awards are currently permitted under the Incentive Plan, Broad
Based Plans or Directors&#146; Compensation Plan. The EICP will also provide for the granting of performance stock, restricted stock and other stock-based and cash-based awards including deferred stock units to our non-employee directors.
</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>How many shares of Common Stock may be issued under the EICP? </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman"
SIZE="2">As of February&nbsp;13, 2007, of the 38,000,000 shares previously approved by the stockholders, there were 13,220,127 shares of our Common Stock subject to issuance pursuant to outstanding awards under the Incentive Plan and 5,044,782
shares reserved for future awards under the Incentive Plan. If this proposal is adopted, the number of shares of our Common Stock reserved for future awards under the EICP will be increased by 14,000,000 shares, to 19,044,782 shares, so that the
maximum number of shares of our Common Stock which may be issued under the EICP in the future will be 19,044,782 shares plus the 13,220,127 shares subject to already outstanding awards. Of those shares, the aggregate number of shares which may be
issued under the EICP for any awards made on or after February&nbsp;13, 2007, other than awards of stock options and stock appreciation rights, will be limited to 6,348,261 shares, which is one-third of the 19,044,782 shares reserved for future
issuance under the EICP. If an award previously granted under the Incentive Plan or granted under the EICP terminates, expires or lapses for any reason, or if all of the shares that could be issued under the award are not issued, for example because
the award is settled in cash, then the shares not issued may be used for future awards. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The following table provides information about all of the
Company&#146;s equity compensation plans as of December&nbsp;31, 2006: </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Equity Compensation Plan Information </B></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" ALIGN="center">

<TR>
<TD WIDTH="31%"></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" WIDTH="15%"></TD>
<TD></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" WIDTH="15%"></TD>
<TD></TD>
<TD></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" WIDTH="15%"></TD>
<TD></TD></TR>
<TR>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" ALIGN="center" STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM:1px solid #000000"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Plan Category</B></FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM:1px solid #000000"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" ALIGN="center" STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM:1px solid #000000"> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>(a)</B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:1px"
ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Number of<BR>securities to be<BR>issued upon<BR>exercise of<BR>outstanding&nbsp;options,<BR>warrants&nbsp;and&nbsp;rights</B></FONT></P></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM:1px solid #000000"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" COLSPAN="2" ALIGN="center" STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM:1px solid #000000"> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>(b)</B></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:1px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Weighted-average<BR>exercise price of<BR>outstanding&nbsp;options,<BR>warrants&nbsp;and&nbsp;rights</B></FONT></P></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM:1px solid #000000"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" ALIGN="center" STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM:1px solid #000000"> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>(c)</B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:1px"
ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Number of<BR>securities remaining<BR>available for future<BR>issuance under<BR>equity&nbsp;compensation<BR>plans (excluding<BR>securities reflected<BR>in column (a))</B></FONT></P></TD></TR>
<TR>
<TD VALIGN="top"> <P STYLE="margin-left:1.00em; text-indent:-1.00em"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Equity compensation plans approved by security holders</FONT><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1" COLOR="#000000"><SUP>(1)</SUP></FONT><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2" COLOR="#000000"></FONT></P></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" ALIGN="right"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">12,443,213</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

<TR>

<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" ALIGN="right"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">6,337,689</FONT></TD></TR>
<TR STYLE="font-size:1px">
<TD VALIGN="bottom"></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom">&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" STYLE="border-top:3px double #000000">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom">&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>

</TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P><HR WIDTH="21%" SIZE="1" NOSHADE COLOR="#000000" ALIGN="left"> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">64 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">


 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>

<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">(1)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">Column (a)&nbsp;includes stock options granted under the stockholder-approved Incentive Plan. The securities available for future issuance in column (c)&nbsp;are not allocated to
any specific type of award under the Incentive Plan, but are available generally for future awards of stock options, PSUs and RSUs. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">(2)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">Column (a)&nbsp;includes 1,175,500 stock options outstanding that were granted under the Broad Based Stock Option Plan. In July 2004, the Company announced a worldwide stock option
grant under the Broad Based Stock Option Plan, which provided over 13,000 eligible employees with a grant of 100 non-qualified stock options each. The stock options were granted at a price of $46.44 per share which equates to 100% of the fair market
value of our Common Stock on the date of grant (determined as the closing price on the New York Stock Exchange on the trading day immediately preceding the date the stock options were granted), have a term of ten years and will vest on July&nbsp;19,
2009. In 1996, our Board of Directors approved a worldwide stock option grant, called HSY Growth, under the Broad Based Stock Option Plan. HSY Growth provided all eligible employees with a one-time grant of 200 non-qualified stock options. Under HSY
Growth, over 2,471,400 stock options were granted on January&nbsp;7, 1997 with an exercise price of $22.25, which equates to 100% of the fair market value of our Common Stock on the date of grant (determined as the closing price on the New York
Stock Exchange on the trading day immediately preceding the date the stock options were granted). The stock options vested at the end of five years and expired on January&nbsp;6, 2007. Column (c)&nbsp;includes 972,400 stock options under the Broad
Based Stock Option Plan remaining available for future issuance as of December&nbsp;31, 2006. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:3%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">Column (a)&nbsp;also includes
236,400 stock options granted to our Chief Executive Officer, Mr.&nbsp;Lenny, outside of the Incentive Plan in connection with his recruitment. The stock options were granted on March&nbsp;12, 2001 with an exercise price of $32.33, became fully
vested on March&nbsp;12, 2005, and have a ten-year term. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:3%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">Column (c)&nbsp;also includes 169,990 shares remaining available for future
issuance under the Directors&#146; Compensation Plan as of December&nbsp;31, 2006. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">If our Common Stock is changed into or exchanged for a different kind
or number of shares of stock or securities of the Company or another entity as a result of a merger or recapitalization, for example, or if the number of shares of our Common Stock is increased due to a stock dividend or stock split, then the number
and kind of shares issuable under the EICP, the limitations on the number of shares which may be issued to or made subject to awards granted to an individual and the shares subject to outstanding awards and the terms of those awards will be
appropriately adjusted as necessary to reflect the change in our Common Stock. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">In keeping with good corporate governance practices, the EICP expressly
prohibits the re-pricing of stock options and SARs. Furthermore, the EICP requires that the exercise price of stock options and SARs cannot be less than the closing price of the Common Stock on the date of grant, so the granting of discounted stock
options or SARs or &#147;back-dated&#148; stock options or SARs is prohibited. In addition, the EICP does not contain a so-called &#147;evergreen&#148; provision that would automatically increase the share pool each year based on a specified
formula. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>How is the EICP administered? </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The Committee
will administer the EICP. Subject to the terms of the EICP and except as described below with respect to awards granted to non-employee directors or our Chief Executive Officer, the Committee has the sole discretion to determine the employees and
service providers who shall be granted awards, the size and types of these awards, and the terms and conditions of these awards. The Committee may delegate to one or more officers or directors appointed by the Committee its authority to grant and
administer awards, but only the Committee can make awards to our executive officers. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The Board of Directors administers awards to the non-employee
directors and the independent directors of the Board administer awards to the Chief Executive Officer. </FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">65 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Who is eligible to receive awards? </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Employees of the Company and its subsidiaries worldwide are eligible to be selected to receive one or more awards. Individuals who provide services to the Company as consultants, or as contractors or through agencies
per local custom or practice may also be granted awards under the EICP. We cannot determine the actual number of individuals who will receive awards under the EICP because eligibility for participation in the EICP is at the discretion of the
Committee. As of December&nbsp;31, 2006, there were approximately 15,000 full and part-time Hershey employees. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The EICP also provides for the grant of
awards to our non-employee directors. There are currently nine non-employee directors on our Board. The Board will determine and administer the awards to non-employee directors. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>What are annual incentive awards? </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Currently, we make our annual cash incentive awards for the Company&#146;s
executive officers under the annual incentive program (AIP) of the Incentive Plan. This approach is continued under the EICP. Annual cash incentive awards for employees not eligible to participate in the AIP are made under the Broad Based Annual
Incentive Plan. These awards would also be made under the EICP. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The Committee determines the individual cash awards which the participants are eligible to
receive and the performance goals that must be achieved in order to earn the annual incentive, but during any calendar year, no participant may receive an AIP award in excess of $10 million. See the Executive Compensation section of this proxy
statement, beginning on page 33, for more information about AIP awards made to our named executive officers under the Incentive Plan in 2006 and 2007. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman"
SIZE="2"><B>What are performance stock units and performance stock awards? </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Performance stock units and performance stock awards result in a payment to
a participant only if performance goals that the Committee establishes are satisfied. The initial value of each performance stock unit and each performance stock award is equal to the fair market value (on the date of grant) of a share of our Common
Stock. The Committee will determine the applicable performance goals, which may be applied on a Company-wide or an individual business unit basis, as deemed appropriate in light of the participant&#146;s specific responsibilities. Please refer to
the discussion below about performance goals for more information. Depending upon the level of achievement of the performance goals, the number of performance stock units or performance stock shares earned at the end of the performance measurement
period may be more or less than the initial value, and will be zero if the minimum performance goals are not achieved. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">In addition to the performance
requirements discussed above, performance stock units and performance stock are subject to additional limits set forth in the EICP. During any calendar year, no participant may receive more than 500,000 performance stock units or shares of
performance stock. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">We will issue a share of Common Stock or pay cash equal to the fair market value of a share of Common Stock for each performance stock
unit earned (subject to required tax withholding), as determined by the Committee. We issue shares of Common Stock at the time a performance stock award is made, but the shares cannot be transferred or sold by the participant until they are earned.
</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">See the Executive Compensation section of this proxy statement for additional information about performance stock units previously granted to our named
executive officers under the Incentive Plan. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">66 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">


 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>What are stock options? </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman"
SIZE="2">The Committee may grant non-qualified stock options to eligible participants under the EICP. The Committee will determine the number of shares covered by each option, but during any calendar year, no participant may be granted options for
more than 500,000 shares (1,000,000 shares, if made for recruitment in the participant&#146;s initial year of participation). </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The Committee sets the price
of the shares of our Common Stock subject to each stock option, which cannot be less than 100% of the fair market value on the date of grant of the shares covered by the option. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The exercise price of each option must be paid in full at the time of exercise. The Committee also may permit payment through the tender of shares of our Common Stock, or by any other means that the Committee
determines to be consistent with the EICP&#146;s purpose. Any taxes required to be withheld must be satisfied by the participant at the time of exercise, either through a cash payment or through withholding of shares that would otherwise be issued
at the time of exercise. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Options become exercisable at the times and on the terms established by the Committee. Options expire at the times established by
the Committee, which may not be more than ten years after the date of grant. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">See the Executive Compensation section of this proxy statement for more
information about stock options previously granted to our named executive officers under the Incentive Plan. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>What are stock appreciation rights (SARs)?
</B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">SARs are like stock options, except that no exercise price is required to be paid. Upon exercise of a SAR, the participant will receive payment equal
to the increase in the fair market value of a share of our Common Stock on the date of exercise over the grant price (fair market value of a share on the grant date) times the number of shares with respect to which the SAR is exercised. The
Committee will determine the terms and conditions of each SAR. The Committee will determine the number of shares covered by each SAR, but during any calendar year no participant may be granted SARs for more than 500,000 shares (1,000,000 if made for
recruitment in the participant&#146;s initial year of participation). SARs may be paid in cash or shares of our Common Stock (subject to required tax withholding), as determined by the Committee. SARs are exercisable at the times and on the terms
established by the Committee. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>What are restricted stock awards and restricted stock units? </B></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Restricted stock awards and restricted stock units are shares of our Common Stock or rights reflecting the value of shares of our Common Stock that vest in accordance
with terms and conditions established by the Committee. The Committee will determine the number of shares subject to a restricted stock or restricted stock unit award, but during any calendar year no participant may be granted more than 500,000
shares. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">In determining whether an award of restricted stock or restricted stock units should be made, and/or the vesting schedule for an award, the
Committee may impose whatever conditions to vesting it determines to be appropriate, which may include a requirement that vesting will occur only if performance goals established by the Committee are satisfied. See the discussion below regarding
performance goals for more information. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">We will issue a share of our Common Stock or pay cash equal to the fair market value of a share of Common Stock
for each restricted stock unit that vests, as permitted by the Committee. Awards </FONT>
</P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">67 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">
<FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">are subject to required tax withholding. We issue shares of our Common Stock at the time a restricted stock award is made, but the shares cannot be
transferred or sold by the participant until they vest. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">See the Executive Compensation section of this proxy statement for more information about
restricted stock units granted under the Incentive Plan. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>What are other cash-based awards and stock-based awards? </B></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Currently, awards under the Incentive Plan, Broad Based Plans and Directors&#146; Compensation Plan are limited to annual cash incentive awards, performance stock units,
restricted stock units, stock options and SARs. The EICP permits the Committee to grant other forms of cash-based or stock-based awards with such terms and conditions as the Committee determines. The Board determined to include this provision in
order for Hershey to have flexibility to develop additional forms of awards that may not fit within the specific types of awards discussed above. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman"
SIZE="2">Cash-based and stock-based awards are subject to additional limits set forth in the EICP. During any calendar year, no participant may receive a cash-based award with a value in excess of $10&nbsp;million or a stock-based award in excess of
500,000 shares. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">We will issue shares of our Common Stock or pay cash equal to the fair market value of the shares of our Common Stock subject to any award
when such awards are vested or earned, subject to required tax withholding. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>What are performance goals? </B></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The Committee in its discretion may make performance goals applicable to a participant with respect to an award. The Committee determines the performance goal, the
length of the period over which performance against the goal is to be measured and the number of shares or cash to be paid based upon the extent to which the performance goal is achieved. Certain additional provisions apply to awards made to
executive officers which are intended to meet the tax deductibility rules of section 162(m) of the Internal Revenue Code. The EICP permits the Committee to reduce any award payment, notwithstanding the achievement of a performance goal. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Currently, the Incentive Plan provides that the Committee may base the performance goals on one or more of the following performance factors: earnings per share,
return on net assets, market share, control of costs, net sales, cash flow, economic value-added measures, sales growth, earnings growth, stock price, return on equity, financial ratings, regulatory compliance, achievement of balance sheet or income
statement objectives, or other financial, accounting or quantitative objectives established by the Committee. The EICP incorporates these concepts and adds additional factors. As a result, the Committee may base a performance goal on one or more of
the following: net earnings or net income (before or after taxes), earnings per share, net sales or revenue growth, net operating profit, return measures (including, but not limited to, return on assets, capital, invested capital, equity, revenue,
or sales), cash flow (including, but not limited to, operating cash flow, free cash flow, and cash flow return on equity), earnings before or after taxes, interest, depreciation, and/or amortization, gross or operating margins, productivity ratios,
share price (including, but not limited to, growth measures and total shareholder return), expense targets, margins, operating efficiency, market share, customer satisfaction, and/or balance sheet measures (including but not limited to, working
capital amounts and levels of short- and long-term debt). </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">68 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">


 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Performance goals may be particular to a participant or the division, line of business or other unit in which the
participant works, or the Company generally, and may be absolute in their terms or measured against or in relationship to the performance of a peer group or other external or internal measure. A performance goal may include or exclude items to
measure specific objectives, including, without limitation, extraordinary or other non-recurring items, acquisitions and divestitures, internal restructuring and reorganizations, accounting charges and effects of accounting changes. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>What awards can be made to non-employee directors? </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Our non-employee
directors currently receive an annual restricted stock unit grant and may elect to convert their cash retainer payments into Common Stock shares at the time of payment or into deferred stock units under the Directors&#146; Compensation Plan. If the
EICP is approved by the stockholders, the restricted stock units, deferred stock units and Common Stock shares will be treated as awards made from the shares available under the EICP. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The EICP also will permit the Board to use other types of awards, including stock options or SARs, as part of the compensation package paid to our non-employee directors. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">See the Director Compensation section of this proxy statement, beginning on page 18, for more information about compensation paid to our non-employee directors.
</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Are awards transferable? </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">In general, awards granted
under the EICP may not be sold, transferred, pledged or assigned, other than by will or by the applicable laws of descent and distribution, and during a recipient&#146;s lifetime any awards may be exercised only by the recipient. Notwithstanding the
above, the Committee (or the Board, in the case of awards granted to non-employee directors) may, in its discretion, permit awards to be transferred to an individual or entity other than the Company subject to any restrictions the Committee or the
Board may impose. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>How are dividends treated under awards? </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman"
SIZE="2">Recipients of awards may be entitled to receive cash or stock dividends, or cash payments in amounts equivalent to cash or stock dividends declared with respect to shares of our Common Stock, and the Committee or the Board may provide that
these amounts shall be deemed to have been reinvested in additional shares of our Common Stock or otherwise reinvested. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>What are the effects of a
change in control? </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Upon a change in control of Hershey, all outstanding stock options and SARs and all restricted stock unit and restricted stock
awards will fully vest, unless the Committee provided otherwise in the award agreement. The effect of a change in control on performance-based and other awards will be as the Committee determines. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Currently, a change in control will occur if: </FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">there is an unwelcome change in the majority of the members of the Board; </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P
STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">a person or group acquires shares of Common Stock and/or Class B Common Stock representing 25% or more of the shares or the votes represented by the shares and the
Milton Hershey School Trust no longer owns more than 50% of the voting power; or </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">the stockholders approve a business combination or sale of substantially all the Company&#146;s assets after which the Milton Hershey School Trust will no longer
own more than 50% of the voting power of the combined business or purchaser of assets. </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">69 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>What are the tax aspects of the EICP? </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">A recipient of a stock option or SAR will not have taxable income upon the grant of the option or SAR. For options and SARs the participant will recognize ordinary taxable income on exercise equal to the increase of
the fair market value of the shares over the exercise price on the date of exercise. In the United States, any gain or loss recognized upon any later disposition of the shares generally will be capital gain or loss. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Unless the participant elects to be taxed at the time of receipt of an award of restricted stock or performance stock, the participant will not have taxable income until
the restricted stock or performance stock vests. The taxable income will be the fair market value of the shares at the time of vesting. A recipient of restricted stock units, performance stock units, or deferred stock units or other stock-based
awards and cash awards will not have taxable income until the award is paid. The participant will recognize taxable income equal to the fair market value of the shares or the amount of cash received by the participant. In addition, section&nbsp;409A
of the Internal Revenue Code imposes certain restrictions on deferred compensation arrangements. Awards that are treated as deferred compensation under section&nbsp;409A are intended to meet the requirements of that section. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">At the discretion of the Committee, the EICP allows a participant to satisfy tax withholding requirements under U.S. federal and state tax laws or applicable foreign tax
laws in connection with the exercise or receipt of an award by electing to have shares of Common Stock withheld, or by delivering to us already-owned shares of our Common Stock, having a value equal to the amount required to be withheld. If shares
of our Common Stock are withheld to satisfy a participant&#146;s tax withholding obligations with respect to an award, then the withheld shares will not be available again for issuance under the EICP. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">We will be entitled to a tax deduction in connection with an award under the EICP only in an amount equal to the ordinary taxable income realized by the participant and
at the time the participant recognizes the income. Section&nbsp;162(m)&nbsp;of the Internal Revenue Code contains special rules&nbsp;regarding the federal income tax deductibility of compensation paid to our Chief Executive Officer and certain other
executive officers. The general rule&nbsp;is that annual compensation paid to the Chief Executive Officer or other named executive officers will be deductible only to the extent that it does not exceed $1,000,000. However, we can preserve the
deductibility of certain compensation in excess of $1,000,000 if we comply with conditions imposed by section&nbsp;162(m), including the establishment of a maximum number of shares with respect to which awards may be granted to any one employee
during one year, and for awards other than options and SARs, the Committee setting performance goals which must be achieved prior to payment of the awards. The EICP is designed to enable the Committee to grant awards that satisfy the requirements of
section&nbsp;162(m), thereby allowing us to minimize the effect of section 162(m) on our federal income tax deduction in connection with these awards. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The
tax discussion above is based on U.S. income tax laws as currently in effect and is not intended to be a complete discussion of or to address the tax treatment under any foreign jurisdiction or any state or local laws. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>What awards will be made under the EICP? </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Awards under the EICP will
be made at the discretion of the Committee, except for awards to our CEO that will be made by the independent members of our Board or awards to our non-employee directors that will be made by our Board. The Committee, the independent directors and
the Board have not made any decisions on the amount and type of awards that are to be made under </FONT>
</P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">70 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">


 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">
<FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">the EICP to participants in future years. The following table sets forth information concerning the following awards made to or earned by the following
persons in calendar year 2006: </FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

<TD COLSPAN="1" NOWRAP VALIGN="bottom"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" STYLE="BORDER-LEFT:1px solid #000000"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="right" COLSPAN="1" VALIGN="bottom"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#151;</FONT></TD>
<TD COLSPAN="1" NOWRAP VALIGN="bottom"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" STYLE="BORDER-LEFT:1px solid #000000"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="right" COLSPAN="1" VALIGN="bottom"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#151;</FONT></TD>
<TD COLSPAN="1" NOWRAP VALIGN="bottom" STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT:1px solid #000000; padding-right:8px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD></TR>
<TR>
